course.name: Water and Wastewater Engineering
course.description: Introduction to basic concepts of water quality, fundamentals of water and wastewater treatment processes, analysis of treatment process flowsheets, analysis of water quality management alternatives.
course.prerequisites: CIVL 1140 OR CIVL 2410

reviews.author: shirayuki653
reviews.title: A engine core with little calculation
reviews.comment_content:
This is an introduction to water treatment processes.The contents include:

1.Basic concepts of water quality,
2.Drinking water treatment(coagulation, flocculation, sedimentation,filtration and disinfection)
3. Wastewater treatment (biological process)
4. Sludge disposal

The topics are very standard materials which covers the basics of water treatment processes.Compared to other civil courses, this course need more chemistry rather than maths. All the calculations are just plugging in numbers based on the equation derived. The hardest part is the mass balance using CFSTR model. There will be many equations coming out which may be confusing.Besides, this is not a broad base course like 2410 so this will be easier to follow up.

This is a required course for CIEV students and there are also some CEEV students taking taking this course, but overall the number of students taking this course is less than 20.
reviews.comment_teaching:
This a lab-based course,but due to the pandemic the lab session is conducted in Zoom tutorial which makes things troublesome.Imagine how frustrating it is on watching the color change of the indicator using a 144p  recording  This is simply a must but also a non sense to google what is the lab doing after the session. Why I need to waste f**king 10 hours on watching this stuff?

On top of that , the lab technician is the actual course coordinator ans he is in charge for the labs , assignments and also the final. He is also in charge for teaching nearly half of the course. To be honest, his teaching is a bit boring but at least he is responsive to the emails and his explanations are quite good.

For professor Wu, I think his teaching is just fine.
reviews.comment_grading:
Assignment: 79.25 % ( 5% each, 4 in total) ,I don't know why I screw up 2 of them
Lab: 91.67% ( 10% each, 3 reports in total) There are also one simple presentation which to screen out who are the free riders.
Final: The TA refused to respond me on the mark of final, I guess maybe slightly above mean.Note that this year the exam is open-book.

Turns out I got B+, the grade is quite lenient I guess. Perhaps this is because of the small class size.
reviews.comment_workload:
Quite low compared to other 3000-level CIVL courses ( but still substantial)

The homework is just an exercise on how to plugging in numbers

However,the all lab reports need 2-3 days to finish them, since students are asked to do the 8-10 page report IN PERSON.

reviews.author: Gabic
reviews.title: Water and Wastewater Engineering
reviews.comment_content: This is an introduction to water treatment processes, including concepts of water quality, conventional drinking water treatment processes, such as coagulation, flocculation, sedimentation, filtration and disinfection, conventional wastewater treatment processes ( basically biological systems) and a little bit of sludge disposal.
reviews.comment_teaching: The teaching style is traditional. There are also lab sessions delivered by the TAs and laboratory technicians.
reviews.comment_workload:
There are at least 4 easy assignments, 3 lab reports and 1 presentation. The lab reports demand more time (8-10 pages). The presentation is about one of the lab sessions.
This is a course with a moderate workload.

reviews.comment_workload:
Assignment (20%):
Easy Assignment 5% x 4
Cleaner Concept
Notes are insufficient; a Google search is required.

Lab (30%):
The lab has Pre-lab and Lab.
Pre-lab teaches you to use the equipment.
The lab does the experiment.
One week for Lab Report which has the format to follow. (15-20 pages) 10% x 3

Presentation:
14 people were divided into 2 groups (Group A and Group B)
Each group has 45 mins for 1 lab session.

Final (3 hrs.) (100 marks) (50%):
Part I Short Question (30 marks)
(a) Mandatory questions --- 3 marks x 5 Questions
(b) Optional questions (Choose 5 from the following 10 questions) --- 3 marks x 5 Questions

Bonus Question (10 marks)

Part II Long Questions (70 marks)
1. Total alkalinity (10 marks)
2. Flocculation (15 marks)
3. CT value (15 marks)
4. Design (30 marks)

Overall:
The assignment and lab results were nearly the same for everyone. The final is particularly important. But the most important is bonus points (10%) which are given to students who actively participated in the lecture (i.e., attendance, asking and answering questions).
